citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
An adult alpaca "Curly" has an abnormal condition on the tops of the ears and two wounds on the side of her neck that
are not currently under veterinary care. The top half of both ears have complete hairloss and the skin in grey, dry and
cracked. There is some moist red tissue between the cracks on both ears. There are two small wounds are located on the
lower half of the neck with one of each side of the neck, they are approximately 1 inch by 1/4 inch in size. There is bright
red tissue exposed on each of these wounds. The facility representative states this animal has had issues with her ears
since young and the flies have been especially bad this year. In year's past, they have used a salve on her ears but
haven't applied anything to her this year. The facility had not noticed this condition and had not contacted a licensed
veterinarian at the time of inspection. Failure to provide adequate veterinary care for these wounds may result in further
illness in the animal. The facility must use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and
injuries. This alpaca must be evaluated by a licensed veterinarian to create an effective treatment plan for these
conditions.
To be corrected by: 15-August-2023

The facility's employees are not readily identifiable at the time of inspection, each were wearing non-facility affiliated t-
shirts. The inspector was only able to figure out who the employees were when they were seen applying fly spray to the
animals. Employees that are not readily identifiable make it difficult for the public to find if an concern of human or animal
safety arises. A responsible, knowledgeable, and readily identifiable employee or attendant must be present at all times
during periods of public contact.
To be corrected by: 14-August-2023

The pelleted food for one domestic pig had an accumulation of live flies in and around the food receptacle. There are fly
bags present at the rear of this enclosure but the flies are accumulating at the front of the enclosure around the food bowl.
An accumulation of flies in this animal's only food source may lead to parasites or further illness. The food shall be
wholesome, palatable, and free from contamination and of sufficient quantity and nutritive value to maintain all animals in
good health. The facility must ensure the food provided remains free from pest contamination.
To be corrected by: 15-August-2023

The water receptacles for 9 goats, 3 sheep, 1 steer and 1 domestic pig had a significant buildup of organic material. The
goat and sheep water receptacle had green algae growth floating on top and lining the inside of the receptacle. The steer
and pig water receptacle has a buildup of brown organic material lining the inside of the receptacle. The facility
representative states these are cleaned on Mondays, but it was skipped this week due to the weather.
Buildup of algae and organic material in water does not provide the animals potable water and may lead to health
problems like intestinal parasites and other health problems. Potable water must be provided as often as necessary for
the health and comfort of the animals. All water receptacles shall be kept clean and sanitary. The facility must provide
potable water and ensure the water receptacle is kept clean and sanitary.
To be corrected by: 11-August-2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
